thread.section_title: Financial Review - Business, Finance and Investment News | afr.com
thread.title: KPMG invests in cyber security firm to beef up offering to clients
thread.title_full: KPMG invests in cyber security firm to beef up offering to clients | afr.com

author: Ben Potter
title: KPMG invests in cyber security firm to beef up offering to clients
text:
KPMG Australia chairman Peter Nash, left: "We see it as a great opportunity for us to invest in a company that has got a world-class technology." Paul Jeffers by Ben Potter KPMG Australia will sell cyber security to governments and financial service companies in an attempt to cash in on the growing threat of corporate extortion from global hackers.
KPMG Capital Fund 1, a $US85 million global KPMG venture capital fund funded by the professional services network's member firms, bought into Silicon Valley-based Norse Corp through a $US11.4 million funding deal announced two weeks ago.
The deal allows KPMG firms around the world to seel Norse Corp's "live attack intelligence solutions" â€“ products and services that help companies pre-emptively block cyber attacks, track emerging threats and detect compromises almost as they happen.
The investments comes amid mounting concern about a rising tide of cyber attacks from rival governments such as China or hackers working for foreign corporations and a lack of preparedness on Australian corporate boards.
In Australia retailers Kmart and David Jones disclosed this month that their customer databases had been hacked, and around the world cheating website Ashley Madison, Sony Corporation, Visa and MasterCard and even the US government have fallen victim to cyber breaches of customer and employee data.
Mark Tims, a KPMG Australia cyber security partner, said the hacking threat was "just exploding" and Australia was not immune just because it sits on the other side of the world from the source of many cyber threats.
"The cyber threat is becoming more acute and what organisations, governments, banks [and firms] across all sectors are struggling with is trying to keep up with the latest vulnerability and the latest threats to their organisations," Mr Tims said.
"This is actually happening in Australia. There's been a long-held notion that it's not going to happen to us, that it's not going to happen here. Well, the fact is that it is happening here, it's happening to corporations and to governments, and the need to invest and the need to be vigilant is just increasing."
 Traditional network security software companies such as McAfee also offer cyber security products.
'Honey traps' hook in threats KPMG was attracted to Norse Corp because it has its own telecommunications network. This allows the company to lay "honey traps" on the network, see how the "bad guys" respond and feed the intelligence back to clients.
"We see it as a great opportunity for us to invest in a company that has got a world-class technology," KPMG Australia chairman Peter Nash said.
Norse Corp also has sensors and "intelligent agents" littered around its network to monitor traffic, identify suspicious activity or traffic from suspect sources, and advise clients if they are likely being attacked and how they should respond in "near real time".
Depending on the time of day the company's " threat map " may show thousands of cyber threats emanating from China and hundreds emanating from Saudi Arabia, the US, India, Germany, Armenia or Bulgaria.
The attacks are overwhelmingly directed at the US, followed by Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates and unidentified "military/government" targets.
KPMG will offer Norse Corp products and services via its network of more than 162,000 advisers across more than 150 countries.
KPMG Capital Fund 1 has invested in five "disruptive" other start-ups. They include companies that monitor and report on social media and public record information on corporations and their suppliers, or dig into an organisation's disparate legacy information systems to track customer engagement and identify where things go wrong.
The fund is now closed, and KPMG Capital is aiming to raise $US200 million ($272 million) to $US300 million from KPMG firms for a second fund to invest in disruptive technologies.
